item.title: These Cute Stickers Will Keep Your Kids from Losing Their Lunchboxes
item.description:
Image credit: Kiddo Tags

It’s a familiar scenario: Your kid comes home from school either without the jacket you sent her with or with a jacket you’ve never seen before. Kids lose stuff, and it’s fine if it’s a onetime thing, but all too often you’re buying their third lunchbox and school started less than a month ago.

Enter Kiddo Tags, a line of adorably customizable stickers that make sure what’s theirs stays theirs.

The tags are dishwasher and microwave safe, waterproof and UV-resistant, so they’re built to last. They’re also totally customizable. Your little guy or girl can choose their favorite colors or icons, and you can add important health information like serious allergies and emergency contact numbers.

And as an added bonus, these will help little Guinevere learn to spell her name in no time.

RELATED: 11 Tasty Vegetarian School Lunches If Turkey Isn’t Your Kid’s Thing
item.author: editor@purewow.com (PureWow)

item.title: 11 Genius Cleaning Gadgets That Will Change Your Life
item.description:

A Dyson Vacuum

item.title: The 7 Best Fall Family Activities That Aren't Another Corn Maze
item.description:
Fall weekends are the best. But hanging out at the crowded pumpkin patch for the fifth weekend in a row? Not so much. Here, seven out-of-the-box fall ideas that you and your kids will love.

RELATED: The Ultimate Fall To-Do List

Image credit: Twenty20

Plant Bulbs for Next Spring

Plant Bulbs for Next Spring

Sure, the clocks are telling us to fall back, but get your kids’ minds springing ahead. Take a trip to your local garden center and let them pick out bulbs to plant now for flowers next year. Tulips and daffodils are both good options for fall garden beds. Have your kids track the progress of their bulbs from the moment they’re in the ground all the way to first bloom.

RELATED: The Secret Reason Your Houseplants Keep Dying

Image credit: Twenty20

Sign Up for a Family Road Race

Sign Up for a Family Road Race

Fall is the perfect time of year to team up for family runs. Look up local running groups and races and set a goal—say, a 2K—by November. Then, every weekend, start the morning with a short family run followed by a yummy brunch. (Bonus: When you’re done, your five-year-old will undoubtedly need a nap.)

Image credit: Twenty20

Hit Up Your Local Farmers' Market

Hit Up Your Local Farmers' Market

Even if you don’t have the whole weekend to take an apple picking trip, plan an hour-long family excursion to your town’s farmers' market. Guide your kids through all the produce or—better yet—send them on a scavenger hunt to find fall veggies by color (like purple eggplant or green apples).

RELATED: The Best Apple-Picking Orchards in America

Image credit: Twenty20

Take Leaf Peeping on the Road

Take Leaf Peeping on the Road

Pile the family into the car for a fall foliage road trip to look for unique and brightly colored autumn leaves. Plus, you can snag the perfect family photo op while you’re out there. Christmas cards? Done.

RELATED: 10 Websites That Make Holiday Cards a Total Breeze

Image credit: Twenty20

Help Your Kids Get Crafty

Help Your Kids Get Crafty

Build a scarecrow for their fall garden, decorate pumpkins and make collages from the leaves they’ve collected. The best part is, you don’t have to leave the house, yet you’ve unlocked hours and hours of family fun.

Image credit: Twenty20

Go Backyard Camping

Go Backyard Camping

It may be too cold for a full-on sleepover, but that doesn’t mean you can’t still pitch a tent. Set it up in your backyard, then head out with the kids in the late afternoon. The sun sets early enough that by 6 or 7 p.m., you’ll be good to start telling ghost stories and roasting s’mores, all before heading inside to go to bed.

 

Image credit: Twenty20

Try a New Fall Festival

Try a New Fall Festival

OK, so one of these may include a corn maze, but it’s worth searching to see what your hometown has planned. For example, Circleville, Ohio has a massive pumpkin show, and Wareham, Massachusetts has a cranberry harvest fest. Just plug the name of your town and the words “fall festival” into Google and you’ll be amazed at all of the options that come up. 

RELATED: No-Carve Pumpkin Ideas to Step Up Your Halloween Game
item.author: editor@purewow.com (PureWow)

item.title: Matcha + White Chocolate = The Best Drink You've Ever Tasted
item.description:
Image credit: Love & Lemons

Matcha—you know, the super-fine green-tea powder—has been trending for quite some time. Hot chocolate—you know, one of the greatest drinks of all time—is never not trending.

But despite our love for both, we never thought to combine the two. Luckily for us, the crew over at Love & Lemons did, and for that, we thank them heartily.

All this recipe calls for is matcha powder, water, milk and white chocolate chips to make a creamy and delicious beverage that you’re probably going to want to sip from now until the end of time. 

Your move, #PSL.

RELATED: Everything You Need to Know About Matcha
item.author: editor@purewow.com (PureWow)

item.title: The Best Produce Grown in Every U.S. State
item.description:
Few things make us feel as much like a grown-up with our life together as leisurely perusing our local farmers’ market. Whether it’s the sweet corn, blueberries or apples that catch our eye, it made it us wonder: What’s the best local produce across the country? Here’s what we found grows best in every state.

Image credit: Twenty20

Alabama: Blackberries

Alabama: Blackberries

Around the end of June, the entire north Alabama landscape blossoms with vines of plump, ripe blackberries—sweet (semi-tart) home Alabama.

Image credit: Twenty20

Alaska: Cabbage

Alaska: Cabbage

Produce thrives during Alaska’s summer sun. In fact, the biggest green cabbage of all time—a freakishly enormous 138-pound vegetable reported by Guinness World Records—was grown in Palmer, Alaska, back in 2010.

Image credit: Twenty20

Arizona: Lettuce

Arizona: Lettuce

You name it: Iceberg, Boston, butter or Bibb...Arizona’s got it.

Image credit: Twenty20

Arkansas: Watermelon

Arkansas: Watermelon

Fun fact: Hillary Clinton told talk-show host Steve Harvey that the first thing she ever heard Bill talk about was watermelons from his home state.

RELATED: One-Ingredient Watermelon Sorbet

Image credit: California Avocados/Facebook

California: Avocados

California: Avocados

Welcome to the land of the B-L-A-T sandwich. In fact, San Diego is the avocado capital of the country, so every time you bite into your avocado, nod your head to Cali.

RELATED: How to Ripen an Avocado in 10 Minutes

Image credit: TWENTY20

Colorado: Marijuana

Colorado: Marijuana

Meet America’s newest cash crop…thanks to this Rocky Mountain state.

RELATED: Sooo, You Can Now Be a Marijuana Sommelier

Image credit: Lyman Orchards/Facebook

Connecticut: Asian Pears

Connecticut: Asian Pears

Pear season isn’t long in Connecticut, but the crisp and sweet fruits are the best around. Head to Lyman Orchards or Bishops Orchards in September to pick your own.

Image credit: Walnut Springs Fruit Farm/Facebook

Delaware: Strawberries

Delaware: Strawberries

It’s the state fruit for a reason. Tiny Delaware has about two dozen U-pick strawberry farms, like Walnut Springs, which are swarmed with pickers in the summer.

Image credit: Halegroves

Florida: Honey Bell Oranges

Florida: Honeybell Oranges

While most of the U.S. is freezing all winter, the Sunshine State is growing these juicy, seedless tangerine-grapefruit hybrids.

Image credit: Dickey Farms/Facebook

Georgia: Peaches

Georgia: Peaches

Monks first brought peaches to St. Simons and Cumberland Island back in the 157; today, the state grows over 40 different varieties. Aaand now we’re craving some peach pie.

Image credit: Twenty20

Hawaii: Pineapple

Hawaii: Pineapple

You know you’re in a tropical paradise when you’re surrounded by pineapples.

Image credit: Famous Idaho Potatoes/Facebook

Idaho: Russet Potatoes

Idaho: Russet Potatoes

The key to these delicious puds: rich, volcanic soil and a combo of warm days and cool nights. Talk about exclusive…

Image credit: Zoran Simin/Getty Images

Illinois: Soybeans

Illinois: Soybeans

Where did you think all that tofu came from?

Image credit: Twenty20

Indiana: Winter Wheat

Indiana: Winter Wheat

Hooray for carbs. These crops are planted during fall and meant to withstand freezing winter temperatures.

Image credit: Twenty20

Iowa: Corn

Iowa: Corn

This Midwestern state produces about 2.5 billion bushels of corn per year. But don’t be fooled: Less than one percent is the type of sweet corn you eat on the cob.

Image credit: Leandro Hernandez/Getty IMages

Kansas: Sorghum

Kansas: Sorghum

This cereal grain looks a lot like corn when it grows. While typically used as a syrup or sweetener, today it’s often used as a gluten-free substitute for wheat flour.

Image credit: Twenty20

Kentucky: Bourbon

Kentucky: Bourbon

It's basically corn.

RELATED: The Ultimate Fall Cocktail Guide

Image credit: Livinus/Getty Images

Louisiana: Sugar Cane

Louisiana: Sugarcane

Why do you think the beignets taste so good?

Image credit: Estes Farm/Facebook

Maine: Blueberries

Maine: Blueberries

There is no summer without fresh-picked Maine blueberries.

RELATED: Blueberry Crumble Pie

Image credit: Twenty20

Maryland: Crabs

Maryland: Crabs

OK, not exactly produce, but blue crabs > fruits and vegetables. Plus, they’re farmed in the sea, which must count for something.

Image credit: Twenty20

Massachusetts: Cranberries

Massachusetts: Cranberries

Southeastern Massachusetts and Cape Cod, in particular, is cranberry bog territory. The harvest for these tiny anti-oxidant rich fruits begins in September and ends before Thanksgiving.

Image credit: Twenty20

Michigan: Cherries

Michigan: Cherries

The summer town of Traverse City, on Michigan’s northern coast, is known as the cherry capital of the states. In the spring, the landscape is covered with pink cherry blossoms, which ripen into sweet and tart cherries come June.

Image credit: Aamodt?s Apple Arm/Facebook

Minnesota: Honeycrisp Apples

Minnesota: Honeycrisp Apples

The Honeycrisp apple, now a favorite across the country, was first developed at the University of Minnesota. In fact, the university gets a royalty every time an orchard plants a honeycrisp tree.

RELATED: Mini Mason Jar Apple Pies Are Adorable and Delicious

Image credit: Twenty20

Mississippi: Maize

Mississippi: Maize

Grain corn, or maize, is essential to Mississippi’s southern comfort cooking. Take hot tamales, for example, a Mississippi Delta specialty typically made with pork filling wrapped in a dried corn husk. Mmmmmm.

Image credit: Twenty20

Missouri: Hay

Missouri: Hay

This state produces more than 8 million tons of hay per year…aka a lot of happy cattle and horses.

Image credit: Twenty20

Montana: Beans

Montana: Beans

Beans, beans, they’re good for your heart, and dried beans—like black, pinto, lentil and garbanzo—are also
becoming an increasingly important crop in Montana.

Image credit: Perystskyy/Getty Images

Nebraska: Sugarbeets

Nebraska: Sugar beets

If you have a sweet tooth, listen up. Sugar beets, which contain a high amount of sucrose in their roots, are used in sucrose production as a substitute for sugarcane.

Image credit: Laraag/Getty Images

Nevada: Alfalfa Seed

Nevada: Alfalfa Seed

You know those little sprouts that appear on your tuna sandwich or veggie wrap? Blame it on Nevada.

Image credit: Twenty20

New Hampshire: Pumpkin

New Hampshire: Pumpkins

It’s only natural that this state, known for its gorgeous fall foliage, would have some great pumpkin farms. In fact, one of the country’s best pumpkin festivals takes place in Keene each October.

Image credit: Twenty20

New Jersey: Tomatoes

New Jersey: Tomatoes

Rutgers University is spearheading the effort to bring back the glory of the Jersey tomato with the development of the “Rutgers 250” plant, an old-fashioned tomato with an old-fashioned taste.

RELATED: The Best Damn Tomato Soup

Image credit: @chilechica/Instagram

New Mexico: Green Chile Pepper

New Mexico: GREEN CHILE PEPPERS

Chile peppers are a huge part of New Mexican culture—so much so that New Mexico State University has an entire department dedicated to the education and research of chile peppers. Which reminds us: Don’t visit Santa Fe without trying the green chile enchiladas at The Shed. (You’re welcome.)

Image credit: Fishkill Farms/Facebook

New York: Cortland Apple

NEW YORK: CORTLAND APPLES

The most emblematic apple in the apple state is the Cortland, a sweet-tart apple with a white, crisp interior that was developed in New York back in 1898.

Image credit: Sweet Potatoes/Facebook

North Carolina: Sweet Potato

NORTH CAROLINA: SWEET POTATOES

We shutter to imagine a world in which there are only regular potatoes. And with Thanksgiving approaching quickly, let’s take a second to thank North Carolina for some of fall’s most important produce.

Image credit: Twenty20

North Dakota: Sunflowers

North Dakota: Sunflowers

Is there anything as cheerful as bright, yellow fields of fields of sunflowers as far as the eye can see? Nope.

Image credit: @uriboun/Instagram

Ohio: Pawpaw

Ohio: Pawpaw

If you’ve never heard of a pawpaw, Ohio’s state fruit, you’re not alone. This semi-tropical plant is often described as a cross between a mango and a banana. We hear a smoothie calling our name.

Image credit: Twenty20

Oklahoma: Peanuts

Oklahoma: Peanuts

Peanut butter! Cracker Jacks! Peanut M&Ms! Thank goodness for Oklahoma.

Image credit: Twenty20

Oregon: Hops

Oregon: Hops

Oregon’s Willamette Valley is one of the largest hops-producing areas in the world. So it makes total sense that Portland is one of the craft beer capitals of the U.S.

Image credit: Twenty20

Pennsylvania: Mushrooms

Pennsylvania: Mushrooms

Kennett Square, a small town in Chester County, produces one half of America’s mushrooms—400 million pounds per year—made up of mostly portobellos and white mushrooms.

Image credit: @scramp/instagtam

Rhode Island: RI Greening Apple

Rhode Island: RI Greening Apples

The official fruit of the Ocean State is the perfect ingredient for an old-fashioned apple pie.

Image credit: Ladafolio/Getty Images

South Carolina: Collard Greens

South Carolina: Collard Greens

Thanks to South Carolina’s year-long moderate climate, this leafy green is one of the only vegetables that’s literally always in season.

Image credit: Twenty20

South Dakota: Flaxseed

South Dakota: Flaxseed

Blend some of these seeds into your morning smoothie for all the fiber you need.

RELATED: 5 Trendy Foods That Actually Give You Energy

Image credit: Jack Daniel's/Facebook

Tennessee: Jack Daniels

Tennessee: Jack Daniel's Whiskey

Take a break from all those fruits and veggies. You deserve this.

Image credit: Twenty20

Texas: Pecans

Texas: Pecans

Texas learned the art of pecan grafting and began farming the nuts commercially in the late 1800s. Pecan pie, anyone?

Image credit: Twenty20

Utah: Barley

Utah: Barley

Barley has a bad rap for being a pretty unsexy grain, but remember: It’s used to make beer and whiskey.

Image credit: Twenty20

Vermont: Maple Syrup

Vermont: Maple Syrup

OK, we know maple syrup isn’t produce per sé, but it’s more essential to your pancakes than blueberries. And the Green Mountain State is home to hundreds of maple sugar houses that produce over a million gallons of syrup per year. Sweeeeet.

Image credit: @bluelemons/instagram

Virginia: Grapes

Virginia: Grapes

Fun fact: Virginia is one of the most prominent wine-producing states in the country. It’s home to great wineries (don’t miss Bluemont Vineyard and Pearmund Cellars) and more than two dozen grape varieties, which thrive in the state’s mountain region.

Image credit: Twenty20

Washington: Apples

Washington: Apples

Washington State is the number one apple producer in the country, growing over 2.5 million tons every year. To put that in perspective, six out of every ten apples consumed in the U.S. come from Washington, according to the state’s Apple Commission.

RELATED: The Best Apple-Picking Orchards in America

Image credit: Twenty20

West Virginia: Golden Delicious Apple

West Virginia: Golden Delicious Apples

Today, you’ll find Golden Delicious apples across the country. But the first of these prevalent apple trees was found in Clay County, West Virginia, in 1914. The county still hosts an annual four-day Golden Delicious festival in September.

Image credit: Twenty20

Wisconsin: Sweet Corn

Wisconsin: Sweet Corn

Wisconsin summer is synonymous with sweet corn. From June through August local farmers' markets and produce stands are stocked with ears of bright yellow sweet corn.

RELATED: The Best Way to Eat Corn Is Grilled and Covered in Spicy Aioli

Image credit: Twenty20

Wyoming: Livestock

Wyoming: Livestock

Not produce, but hear us out: The reason Wyoming is home to so many grazers (cattle) is because of its favorable grasslands, which are basically produce for the cows. Boom!
item.author: editor@purewow.com (PureWow)

item.title: How to Swaddle a Baby
item.description:
Image credit: Laura Wing-Kamoosi

Being a new parent raises a lot of questions. Like “Why is the earth made up of choking hazards?” Or “Why do strangers insist on trying to touch my baby?” And sometimes, “How in the world do I swaddle my baby so the blanket stays and she finally goes to sleep because it's 3 a.m.?” Watch this swaddling 101 video, and learn how to wrap your little one so she is nice and cozy. And you can all get back to sleep.

item.title: Feeling Anxious? Here's an Easy, Awesome Fix
item.description:
Image credit: Twenty20

OK, you have a big presentation to give at work. That familiar stomach-churning feeling is kicking in. You’re pacing around like a madwoman and your palms are clammy. You’ve done your yoga breaths to no avail. Here, a quick way to calm your nerves in minutes.

What you need: A private space that’s big enough for you to comfortably move around in (an empty conference room, a bathroom stall, a closet, etc.)

What you do: Start moving. That’s it. Whether it’s flailing your arms and shoulders or hopping in place, find a way to shake things out—physically.

Why it works: The burst of movement literally jostles your lymphatic fluid, resets your nervous system and gets feel-good endorphins pumping to ease tension from your body. We first heard the tip at Maha Rose, a delightful little healing center in NYC, and it totally works. Ever seen two dogs get in a scuffle? What’s the first thing they do afterward? Shake it off. And then run about happily as if nothing happened. So the next time you feel jittery or mentally blocked, hop to it.

RELATED: 7 Foods That Can Calm Anxiety
item.author: editor@purewow.com (PureWow)

item.title: How to Turn Off All of Those Annoying iOS 10 Updates
item.description:
Don’t get us wrong: We love our iPhone. And if you’ve updated your software or nabbed the new iPhone 7 (we’re soooo jealous), then you already know iOS 10 comes with tons of cool features. But here are five not-so-great ones we’re definitely turning off. 

RELATED: These Are the Best New Emojis From the iPhone Update

Image credit: Twenty20

Stop Your Phone From Randomly Lighting Up

Stop Your Phone From Randomly Lighting Up

Have you noticed your phone screen brighten at random times, even when there are no new notifications? Now, whenever the internal motion sensor is triggered, the iPhone’s screen lights up, which Apple has dubbed “waking.” It’s not so helpful when you’re at a movie and want to check your messages incognito. To stop this from happening, go to Settings > Display and Brightness > Raise to Wake and switch the toggle off.

Image credit: Apple

Get The Drawing Pad to Stop Popping Up in iMessage

Get The Drawing Pad to Stop Popping Up in iMessage

In the new update, if you open a text message window and turn your phone horizontally, a drawing pad will appear. To switch this off, click the tiny keyboard on the bottom right corner when the drawing pad appears. This will activate the keyboard when the phone is horizontal.

Image credit: Apple

Turn Off the "Press to Unlock" Feature

Turn Off the "Press to Unlock" Feature

The new update has changed the way you unlock your phone. (Ugh, just when we’d gotten the hang of swiping.) The default now requires you to press down the home button in order to unlock it. To undo it, go to Settings > General > Accessibility > Home Button, then select Rest Finger to Open.

Image credit: Apple

Delete Unnecessary Apps That Came with the Phone

Delete Unnecessary Apps That Came with the Phone

Finally, we can all say buh-bye to Pages, Numbers, OneNote and iTunesU (whatever the heck that is). Just press the app on your screen until it wiggles, then click the “X” in the corner to delete. 

Image credit: Apple

Disable iMessage Replies When the Screen Is Locked

Disable iMessage Replies When the Screen Is Locked

In the new OS, anyone can reply to a text message without even unlocking the phone. Apple must have forgotten that toddlers have a way with words (and grabbing iPhones out of moms’ hands). To change this, go to Settings > Touch ID & Passcode > Reply with Message and toggle to the off position.

RELATED: These Are the Best New Emojis from the iPhone Update
item.author: editor@purewow.com (PureWow)

item.title: 8 Under-the-Radar Foodie Towns You Need to Visit
item.description:
Image credit: Lampo

OK, San Francisco, we get it. You have really good food. You too, New York, New Orleans, Charleston and Chicago. Gold stars for all. But if you’ll excuse us, we’ll let everyone else fight over your charms for a little while and turn our attention to the culinary underdogs—smaller towns and cities with surprisingly great food scenes.

RELATED: 11 Secret Restaurants in the U.S. You Don't Know About (but Should)

Image credit: Persimmon

Providence, RI

Providence, RI

Rhode Island may be the smallest state in the country, but when it comes to food, it’s in a sweet spot. It draws talent from New York and Boston, ingredients from the nearby New England coast and has Johnson and Wales, one of the country’s top culinary schools. Make sure to visit the old-school, red-sauce Italian restaurants on Federal Hill and grab some Syrian street food at East Side Pockets near Brown University. For new flavors, try the food trucks at the Providence flea market, tortas at Tallulah’s Taqueria and the Blue Hill-inspired tasting menu at Persimmon.

Image credit: Lampo

Charlottesville, VA

Charlottesville, VA

It’s been one of America’s great college towns since Thomas Jefferson’s time, but there’s way more to offer than beer and ramen. Stop by Feast! at lunchtime for a grilled pimento cheese sandwich. For dinner, brave the lines at Lampo for an authentic Neapolitan pizza, indulge in sophisticated comfort food at Commonwealth or splurge on a romantic night of butter-poached lobster and stuffed quail at Fleurie.

RELATED: The Best Pizza in Every Single State

Image credit: Grand Traverse Pie Company

Traverse City, MI

Traverse City, MI

We would have guessed that Mario Batali spends his summers in Tuscany, not Michigan’s Lower Peninsula. But with the abundance of super-fresh produce, fish and hand-cured meats and cheeses, Traverse City is actually the perfect place for a superstar chef (and anyone else with a good appetite). Your first stop should be the Grand Traverse Pie Company for a slice of cherry. Then make a reservation for farm-to-table fare at The Cooks' House or just-caught Michigan whitefish at The Cove.

RELATED: The 10 Best Pies in the Whole Entire Country

Image credit: La Rambla

McMinnville, OR

McMinnville, OR

Let the bachelorette parties storm Napa and Sonoma and instead head north to Oregon’s Willamette Valley for beautiful scenery and wine tasting that’s just a bit more&hellihellip;peaceful. McMinnville, known for its rolling hills and Pinot Noir, also has some of the best food in the region. We love the rustic, seasonally driven fare at Thistle, the paella and tapas at La Rambla and the famous Dungeness crab and pine nut lasagna at the nearly 40-year-old Nick’s Italian Café.

Image credit: Sokolowski's

Cleveland, OH

Cleveland, OH

OK, so you’ve probably heard of Cleveland. But what you might not know is that it’s been going through a food renaissance. Cleveland’s food halls (think: really exciting food courts) have inspired a nationwide trend, and its West Side Market, which dates back to 1912, is unparalleled. Sokolowski’s is unbeatable for Old World favorites like pierogi and sauerkraut, but Cleveland also has plenty of exciting new bistros—like Michael Simon’s flagship restaurant, Lola.

Image credit: Hoyoung L./Yelp

Marfa, TX

Marfa, TX

This quirky West Texas town is three hours from an airport and boasts a year-round population of only 2,000. But thanks to a thriving art scene (including an installation of a Prada store in the middle of a vast desert) and some seriously good eats, it’s gotten a lot of hype. Your first priority should be a falafel sandwich from the mostly Mediterranean Food Shark truck. After that, head to Cochineal for fancy-pants Chilaquiles and cocktails.

Image credit: Stephanie S./Yelp

Louisville, KY

Louisville, KY

It’s smack-dab in the middle of bourbon country, so you already know the beverages will be on point, but Louisville also has some of the best Southern cooking in the country. We love both the new and old takes: For modern, prix-fixe fare, Edward Lee’s 610 Magnolia is always exquisite. For old-time fine dining, we like the stately 80-year-old Jack Fry’s. For a more casual experience, follow your nose to the smokers at the Frankfort Avenue Beer Depot.

Image credit: Alex's Bistro

Cooperstown, NY

Cooperstown, NY

Baseball fans have been flocking to this upstate New York town for over a century to pay homage to the Hall of Fame. But there are now attractions for the less athletically inclined, too, thanks to the elegant Otesaga resort and the Ommegang Brewery, which also has a great café. Make sure to check out Alex’s Bistro, from former Dean & DeLuca manager Alex Webster, for eats like the Tipsy Spotted Pig—penne alfredo topped with chipotle pulled pork and roast chestnut hash.

RELATED: The 15 Best Food Trucks in the Whole Country
item.author: editor@purewow.com (PureWow)

item.title: The Kind of Miraculous Way to Scramble Eggs Better
item.description:
Image credit: Robyn Mackenzie/Getty Images

There’s nothing quite like a plate of fluffy, silky scrambled eggs. (Seriously, breakfast goals.) But when we make them at home, the texture is never quite fluffy or silky enough. So what is the secret?

Well, it's actually quite surprising. In lieu of a spatula or wooden spoon, use chopsticks to scramble eggs.

Hear us out: Using chopsticks to make tiny circles breaks the eggs into small, fine curds as they cook. This changes the texture for the better. (Hey, star chefs like David Chang swear by it.) They’re also the perfect material to use on a nonstick pan. And if you need to add a little something to coat the pan, use olive oil instead of butter.

Voilà—delicious, fluffy eggs for all.
item.author: editor@purewow.com (PureWow)

item.title: A Super-Easy Eyeliner Trick to Make You Look More Awake
item.description:
Image credit: Twenty20

There are many tricks of the trade when it comes to makeup. Some are passing fads or a tad too fussy for everyday wear (hello, contouring), while others are so easy and impactful that they change the way we get ready forever—like tightlining, an eyeliner technique that’s simple to execute and super effective at making your eyes pop.

What you need: A soft, waterproof eyeliner pencil in a navy blue or indigo color.

What you do: Use your finger to gently pull up your upper eyelid. Then take your liner, start in the inner corner and sketch along the underside of your lashes (where the roots are) in small, back-and-forth motions until you reach the outer corners of your eyes. Note: You want to deposit the pigment where your lashes start—not on the water line (the thin sliver of skin that rims your peepers), which can make your eyes water and cause smudging.

Why it works: Anyone who has ever wielded an eyeliner pencil knows that it's infuriatingly difficult to get right every time. Tightlining is much easier to do since you're drawing a series of short strokes as opposed to one long swoop. And because the pigment is so close to the lash line, it frames your eyes subtly—making it the perfect go-to look for when you don't want to seem too done up. Plus, the navy-blue shade makes the whites of your eyes look brighter.

RELATED: Every Eyeliner Technique You Might Want to Know

item.title: 3 Ways to Take a Nap and Not Wake Up Groggy
item.description:
When you’re having a crazy day, a power nap can make all the difference. But if you usually wake up feeling cranky, you’re doing it wrong. It’s time to learn the fine art of napping. 

Related: 6 Ways to Organize Your Bedroom For Better Sleep

Image credit: Getty Images

If You Have 10 Minutes…

If You Have 10 Minutes...

We’re talking about a quick recharge here. According to a Flinders University study, even a ten-minute snooze will help you feel more alert and improve your cognitive performance. But don’t change into PJs. Instead, lie on your bed or couch fully clothed, with a blanket over you. Keep the shades open to let some natural light stream in—it’ll be easier to wake up again if the room isn’t pitch black. Even if you don’t fall asleep, just lying quietly with your eyes closed should be enough to give you a little boost.

Image credit: Twenty20

If You Have 20 Minutes...

If You Have 20 Minutes...

Try this genius trick called a “caffeine nap.” Right before you lie down, quickly drink a cup of coffee. Caffeine usually takes half an hour to fully kick in. So if you time it right and set your alarm for 20 to 30 minutes, you’ll wake up feeling refreshed, alert and, well, caffeinated.

Image credit: masta4550/Getty Images

If You Have an Hour...

If You Have an Hour...

Here’s where things start to get tricky: The longer you sleep, the more likely it is that the dreaded grogginess will set in. Try the phone app Pzizz to keep your nap from pulling you into the depths of REM sleep. Pop in your headphones and listen to binaural tones customized to the length of your sleep. It’s designed to help you drift off, then gradually wake back up again when your nap is over.

Related: 4 Tips Every Back Sleeper Needs to Know

item.title: A 2-Second Trick to Find Out if You'd Look Good with Short Hair
item.description:
Image credit: PureWow

Now that fall is here, you’ve been feeling tempted to chop off your sun-worn strands. Before you do, you might want to try this nifty trick to determine exactly how you’d look with a significantly shorter 'do. 

What you need: A ruler, a pencil and a mirror.

What you do: Stand in front of the mirror with the side of your face in view. Hold the pencil horizontally so that it’s touching your chin, and then position the ruler vertically beneath your ear so that the pencil and ruler intersect. Next, measure the distance from the bottom of your earlobe to the top of the pencil. 

What you’re looking for: If it’s less than two and a quarter inches from your ear to the pencil, green light—short hair (like a chin-length bob) will look great on you. If it’s more than two and a quarter inches, you may want to consider keeping a bit of length (think: a shoulder-grazing lob or longer).

OK, but why is this true? Apparently, it’s less about face shape and more about the angle of your jawbone (says John Frieda stylist Giles Robinson). There are exceptions to the rule, of course, but this is a good test if you’re toying with the idea of shorter hair. 

Time to call your hairstylist. For once, you know the exact cut you want. 

RELATED: The Very Best Short Haircuts to Try Right Now

item.title: The Easy Way to Keep Guacamole Green for 24 Hours
item.description:
Image credit: Twenty20

It’s a proven fact: Guac and chips are the best party snack of all time. But every time we smash our avocados and assemble the dip ahead of time, it turns brown in five seconds.

Thankfully, we learned an easy hack for keeping guacamole green and fresh. All you need is one ingredient you probably already have in your kitchen: cooking spray. 

Next time you make a bowl of guac, spray the top of the dip with nonstick vegetable oil, olive oil or coconut oil spray. Then cover the dip with plastic wrap and store it in the fridge. Your guacamole should stay fresh for about 24 hours. This trick works to preserve halved avocados, too.

Fiesta crisis averted. Phew.

RELATED: How to Make Avocado Pickles

item.title: This FitBit for Fertility Helps Increase Your Chances of Conceiving
item.description:
Image credit: Ava

You and your partner are starting to talk about having your first—or, gasp, second—kid. But tracking your fertility on the calendar feels like a major chore. 

That’s where the Ava comes in. This FDA-approved ovulation-tracking bracelet detects the most fertile days during your menstrual cycle by collecting data (like your heart rate and skin temperature) that predicts the rise of baby-making hormones. Whoa. 

After that, the info gets zapped off to an app on your phone, then re-organized into a series of graphs that alert you to the days you’re most likely to conceive. (FYI, according to Ava’s own research, women have an average of five fertile days per month.)

Here’s the best part: You only have to wear the bracelet at night, which means you don’t have to worry about deflecting annoying questions from friends (or your prying mother-in-law) about the gadget on your wrist.

OK, so it costs $199 to buy. But that’s a small price to pay if you get a baby out of the deal, don’t you think?

RELATED: 8 Common Conception Myths Busted

item.title: Oooh, You Can Now Make Shareable Grocery Lists on Your iPhone
item.description:
Apples, milk, eggs, dog food…ugh. You have a million things to remember, and a mental checklist of everything your family asked you to pick up at the store isn't one of them. But thanks to the new iOS 10 update, you no longer need to keep a running tally. Use the Notes app to let multiple people collaborate simultaneously.

Image credit: Apple

Step 1

Step 1

Tap the Notes app on your iPhone, then open an iCloud note. (To do this, make sure your notes are shared to your iCloud. Simply go to Settings > iCloud and turn Notes on.)

Image credit: Apple

Step 2

Step 2

Click the icon at the top right (it looks like a person with a plus sign). Add your S.O. via a text message, link or email, then type away. Your collaborator will be able to open up the note on his or her phone and edit and add groceries (chunky peanut butter, please) in real time.

Step 3

Step 3

Don’t forget to add the kiddos, too, if there’s a whole bunch of chores that need to get done before your dinner party on Friday. Now excuse us while we subtly ask for Ben & Jerry’s fro-yo without actually having to say a word. We love you, technology. 

RELATED: How Your iPhone Timer Can Help You Sleep Better

item.title: 6 Bras Every Lady Needs
item.description:
Bras: They’re kind of a necessary evil. Well, until you realize that you don’t need a drawer full of extraneous options. In fact, you only really need six styles. Pin our handy infographic and remember—less is more.

RELATED: 9 Tricks for a Better Fitting Bra

The Only Bras You Need

The Only Bras You Need

See—bra hunting doesn't have to be hard. You just need a tight edit and all your bases covered. Let's chat more about each one.

Image credit: Nubian Skin

A T-Shirt Bra You Can Wear Every Day

A T-Shirt Bra You Can Wear Every Day

Think of this as your lingerie drawer’s MVP. T-shirt bras are simple and practical, with seamless, molded cups that you’ll probably wear more than any other style. Since you’ll getting so much use out of it, make sure to buy neutral colors like nude, black or white, and don’t be afraid to spend a little more than you normally would. 

Get the look: Heidi Klum Intimates ($44); Nubian Skin ($55); La Perla ($114)

Image credit: L'Agent by L'Agent Provocateur

A Statement Bra That's Begging to Be Seen

A Statement Bra That's Begging to Be Seen

Oh hi, sexy. You might not wear this little number as often as your trusty T-shirt bra, but you’ll feel incredible when you do. Depending on your preference, a “statement” could be as subtle as a hint of embellishment or as in-your-face as the Victoria’s Secret Fantasy Bra (just kidding, that’s, like, millions of dollars). When it comes to the lingerie you buy with the intention of showing, you do you.

Get the look: Elle Macpherson Body ($56); L'Agent by L'Agent Provocateur ($69); Ashley Graham ($70)

Image credit: Naja

A Bralette You Can Wear on Days Off

A Bralette You Can Wear on Days Off

This wireless style, with its minimal support, is a bit better for smaller chested ladies, but if you’re wearing it only around the house, does it really matter, as long as it’s comfy? The fabric should be soft and stretchy and make it feel like you’re wearing nothing at all. If you're larger chested, look for a comfortable model that holds you in slightly without compressing everything. 

Get the look: Lunya ($50); Naja ($50); Negative Underwear ($55)

Image credit: Lane Bryant

A Convertible Bra You Can Wear With Several Tops

A Convertible Bra You Can Wear With Several Tops

One-shoulder tops, off-the-shoulder dresses, shirts with crisscrossing straps of varying widths. You've got them all, but you don't want to buy separate bras to wear with them all. That's where a convertible bra comes in. Most can be worn in a bunch of different ways (including the always useful strapless), so you can cover all your bases with just one model. 

Get the look: Lane Bryant ($45); Natori ($64); Wacoal ($65)

RELATED: A Genius Trick for Keeping Your Strapless Bra In Place

Image credit: Nike

A Sports Bra That Protects Your Girls

A Sports Bra That Protects Your Girls

A well-fitting sports bra isn’t just necessary for a comfortable workout; it’s necessary for your health. No matter how small your breasts, a lack of support can lead to back pain, discomfort and tissue damage that could cause stretch marks and sagging.

Get the look: Nike ($50); Soma ($66); Athleta ($68)

RELATED: Does Sleeping in a Bra Really Make Your Boobs Perky?

Image credit: Chantelle

A Push-Up Bra That Makes You Feel Great

A Push-Up Bra That Makes You Feel Great

Va-va-voom. Obviously if you’re smaller chested, this style should create cleavage and the allusion of a few more cup sizes. But if you’re larger chested, don’t rule out this style all together. The right version can lift without adding volume, making your boobs look higher, perfectly rounded and more youthful. 

Get the look: Chantelle ($56); Calvin Klein ($70); Simone Perele ($82)

item.title: How to Get Rid of Garlic Breath Really, Really Fast
item.description:
Image credit: Twenty20

We love you, garlic, we really do. We love you in knot form, on bread and with olive oil and lemons in pretty much every situation.

What we don’t love is how your scent lingers for what seems like an eternity. Especially, on our breath. We know how to get the smell of garlic off our hands, but our breath was another story—until now. 

Turns out, when garlic breath strikes, you should munch on a raw apple. Reason being, the enzyme that makes cut apples turn brown when they're left out acts as a natural deodorant to the sulfides in garlic that cause bad breath.

An apple a day keeps the bad breath away: Garlicky food and close conversations are no longer mutually exclusive.

RELATED: 3 Tricks for Cooking with Garlic

item.title: 5 Things You Should Be Doing When You Condition Your Hair
item.description:
Conditioner is a tricky thing: Skip it and your hair feels like straw. Overdo it and your strands look limp and greasy. But when you get it just right, everything is suddenly softer, silkier and much easier to manage. Here, five ways to up your conditioning game now. 

RELATED: 6 Secrets of Women Who Always Have Perfect Hair

Condition Before You Shampoo

Condition Before You Shampoo

Listen up, fine-haired ladies. The next time you hop into the shower, try conditioning your strands before you lather up with shampoo. This way you’ll still get all of the moisturizing benefits without sacrificing any of that precious volume.

Image credit: @summerbl4ck/Flickr

Distribute It Evenly

Distribute It Evenly

Once you’ve applied your conditioner, run a flat paddle brush through strands from root to tip. Not only will this help to distribute the product evenly throughout your hair, but it will also make detangling a breeze since it gives the strands a protective coating.

Image credit: Twenty20

Apply a Mask to Dry Hair, Not Wet

Apply a Mask to Dry Hair, Not Wet

When your hair is wet, most of the nourishing ingredients in a mask slide off your locks and onto the floor of your shower or tub. When you apply it to dry hair, it soaks everything up like a sponge, leaving you with a smoother finish. To get the most out of your weekly mask, use it as a pre-shampoo treatment. Apply from mid-lengths to ends, let it sit for a few minutes and wash out as you normally would.

Image credit: Twenty20

...But Don't Overdo It

...But Don't Overdo It

Yes, there is such a thing—particularly if whatever it is you’re using says “fortifying” or “strengthening” on the label. These formulas typically contain proteins, which are good in small amounts but can make strands brittle (and risk breakage) if overused.

Image credit: Twenty20

Always Use a Cream or Leave-In Last

Always Use a Cream or Leave-In Last

Everyone—regardless of hair type or texture—can benefit from a leave-in spray, serum or oil after towel drying. You should do this as a final step after every wash to help seal in moisture and protect strands from any heat styling afterward.

RELATED: How Much Hair Product Should I Actually Use?
item.author: editor@purewow.com (PureWow)

item.title: Here's Exactly What to Do with Your Arms in Photos
item.description:
Image credit: Edward Berthelot/Getty Images

Your makeup is on point. You love your outfit. Heck, you even nailed that whole eye-squinching thing Emma Stone is so good at. You’re pretty much a pro when it comes to having your photo taken…except for your flopping, dangling arms. What on earth should you do with them? Fear not: We have some tricks up our sleeves.

RELATED: 8 Secrets of Photogenic Women

Image credit: Edward Berthelot/Getty Images

Tuck Your Hair

Tuck Your Hair

Brush a strand of hair (real or imaginary) behind one ear—preferably on your good side. The placement of your hand draws attention to your face, while your slightly cocked arm looks downright dainty.

Image credit: Edward Berthelot/Getty Images

Pose with a Pal

Pose with a Pal

Fact: Friends make everything better. Especially awkward social situations, like getting your photo taken. The next time someone ambushes you with a camera, casually link arms with whomever you’re next to and smile.

RELATED: 7 Secrets of People Who Are Never, Ever Awkward at Parties

Image credit: Edward Berthelot/Getty Images

Hold Onto Something

Hold Onto Something

…Like a clutch or a classy cocktail. (Any drink will do, really.) Just make sure to loosen your grip. You want your body language to convey ease and comfort, not the fear of being mugged.

RELATED: 13 Reasons to Try a Mini Bag This Fall

Image credit: Christian Vierig/Getty Images

Put One Hand in Your Pocket

Put One Hand in Your Pocket

This is what we call a power pose. Stand straight with one leg slightly jutted out past the other. Then make like you’re reaching into your pocket for something important (like that Black Card—OK, fine, stick of gum). While you’re at it, double up on poses and hang on to your bag, too.

Image credit: Christian Vierig/Getty Images

Keep Them in Motion

Keep Them in Motion

There’s a reason why so many fashion bloggers keep things moving. Walking gives your arms something to do, while naturally coaxing your body into that slimming side angle.

Image credit: Edward Berthelot/Getty Images

Try the Shoulder Drape

Try the Shoulder Drape

When in doubt, drape your coat or sweater over your shoulders. And just like that, you no longer have to worry about what to do with your arms. They’ll remain mostly covered and you’ll look effortlessly chic.

RELATED: The 10 Most Photogenic Clothes You Can Wear
item.author: editor@purewow.com (PureWow)

item.title: The Right Scarf to Wear with Every Outfit
item.description:
Scarf season is here and we’re pumped—they add new life to outfits we’re getting tired of and elevate even the most basic look to new heights. But sometimes we’re just not sure if we should be pairing a chunky knit or a gauzy scarf with our boyfriend jeans (decisions, decisions!). When that happens, consult this handy guide to styling the most common shapes and materials.

RELATED: How to Wear a Scarf

Image credit: Edward Berthelot/Getty Images

Wear a Bandanna with Jeans and a T-Shirt

Wear a Bandanna with Jeans and a T-Shirt

Weekend outfit on point. This look works because a.) you probably already have jeans and a T-shirt (and bandannas are super affordable) and b.) it’s almost impossible to mess up. Tuck your tee into your jeans, tie the banndana loosely around your neck and you’re set.

Image credit: Christian Vierig/Getty Images

Wear a Silk Neck Scarf with an Off-the-Shoulder Top

Wear a Silk Neck Scarf with an Off-the-Shoulder Top

Not only does an off-the-shoulder top show off your collarbone, but it also shows off that pretty scarf you didn’t know what to do with. While all the extra fabric might overwhelm a normal top, a bare-shoulders look is the perfect opportunity to let this ladylike staple shine.

RELATED: 10 Fresh Ways to Wear a Silk Scarf

Image credit: Christian Vierig/Getty Images

Wear a Bold Print with All Black

Wear a Bold Print with All Black

If your scarf is loud like this one, pair it with simple silhouettes and muted colors. Against a background of cropped black jeans and a black blazer, this fiery red number can take center stage.

Image credit: Kirstin Sinclair/Getty Images

Wear a Bulky Knit with a Belt

Wear a Bulky Knit with a Belt

A scarf like this could add unwanted volume—unless you belt it, that is. By cinching it around your narrowest part, you create curves instead of looking like you’re drowning in fabric.

Image credit: Melodie Jeng/Getty Images

Wear a Light, Gauzy Scarf with Slouchy Basics

Wear a Light, Gauzy Scarf with Slouchy Basics

Juxtapose a more feminine and delicate scarf with boyfriend jeans and a looser-fitting black top. The jeans and top keep the scarf from looking too cute, and the scarf softens and dresses up its more androgynous background.

Image credit: Melodie Jeng/Getty Images

Wear a Simple Scarf with a Classic Coat

Wear a Simple Scarf with a Classic Coat

Aaaand this outfit is pretty much perfect. Despite being subdued, the combination of black basics, a camel coat and simple black scarf exudes elegance and keeps you warm without being bulky and puffer-like.

Image credit: Daniel Zuchnik/Getty Images

Wear an Infinity Scarf with Detailed Accents

Wear an Infinity Scarf with Detailed Accents

A loop scarf worn close to your neck draws attention to your torso, so while you’ve got people’s eyes, you might as well give them something to look at. Do that with a sweater with an interesting hem and a luxe blazer with super-cool lapel and pocket details.

RELATED: How to Wear an Infinity Scarf

Image credit: Kirstin Sinclair/Getty Images

Wear a Blanket Scarf Like a Belted Poncho

Wear a Blanket Scarf Like a Belted Poncho

Perfect for the coldest of days, tossing a giant scarf over your shoulders like a poncho (and belting it) is basically like wearing your bed’s comforter—but totally acceptable to the outside world.

RELATED: The 10 Best Blanket Scarves Under $40

Image credit: Kirstin Sinclair/Getty Images

Wear a Skinny Scarf with a Striped Tee and Moto Jacket

Wear a Skinny Scarf with a Striped Tee and Moto Jacket

A little bit rock star, a little bit French girl, this look is all-around cool. A skinny scarf and striped tee look great on their own, but the addition of a tougher jacket adds an interesting layer in terms of style and warmth.

Image credit: Kirstin Sinclair/Getty Images

Wear a Faux Fur Stole with Kooky Details

Wear a Faux Fur Stole with Kooky Details

Not for the faint of heart, a faux fur stole is luxurious and dramatic. If you’re brave enough to go there, you might as well really go there and wear it with equally dramatic pieces like a comically oversize coat, ripped jeans and quirky accessories like this googly-eyed mini bag.

item.title: 7 ATM Mistakes You Might Be Making
item.description:
Image credit: dobok/getty images

You just finished a lovely dinner out when you notice the two most annoying words ever to be written on a menu: cash only. But as you dash off to the ATM, do your best to avoid making these seven mistakes.

RELATED: 5 Places Never to Use a Debit or Credit Card

Image credit: dobok/getty images

Withdrawing Cash From an ATM Without a Vestibule

Withdrawing Cash From an ATM Without a Vestibule

You know the ATMs that are enclosed in a little glass room where you have to swipe your card to gain access? Those are the good ones. They’re extra secure and less susceptible to skimming—i.e. when criminals attach fake card readers or keypads to find out your account details. If you have to use a stand-alone ATM, be sure to give it a once-over first to check for anything fishy.

Image credit: Milenko Bokan/getty images

Forgetting to Shield Your Pin

Forgetting to Shield Your Pin

No, it’s not just about the guy in line behind you. Next-level skimmers will go so far as to set up cameras to record your PIN as you punch it in. A good idea? Use your free hand to cover the numbers. When it comes to your cash, better safe than sorry.

Image credit: JimmyFam/Getty Images

Opening the Door for Others

Opening the Door for Others

Sure, it goes against every fiber of your being, but exhibiting ATM politeness by opening (or holding) the door for others is a pretty big no-no. It’s about security: Swiping your card to gain access to an ATM is a measure put in place for your own safety. Use your best judgment, but ignoring someone who is fumbling to get their card out of their wallet is A-OK.

Image credit: guruXOOX/getty images

Tossing Your Receipt

Tossing Your Receipt

Computers never make mistakes, right? Wrong. An ATM receipt is the best proof of transaction should you spot an error you need to dispute. You don’t have to hold on to it forever—just until your withdrawal (or deposit) clears. Keep in mind: It’s best to shred your receipt before you toss it. (You’d be amazed what an identity thief can do with just your name and partial account number. Yikes.)

RELATED: 7 Important Documents It’s OK to Trash

Image credit: flyfloor/getty images

Using Your Credit Card

Using Your Credit Card

It may feel more secure than using your debit card, but the APR on ATM withdrawals using a credit card is sky-high. (Not to mention, a lot of times you’ll be subjected to additional cash-advance transaction fees.) Even worse, there’s no grace period on paying interest for credit-card cash withdrawals. Bottom line: Emergencies aside, your debit card is really the only card you should be using at the ATM.

RELATED: The One Mistake You’re Making With Your New Chip Credit Card

Image credit: Twenty20

Going All the Way to an ATM Just to Make a Deposit

Going All the Way to an ATM Just to Make a Deposit

It’s time to join the 21st century: Thanks to cameras on phones, mobile deposits are officially a breeze. Just download your bank’s app and log in to your account. To make a deposit, simply sign the check and then snap pics of the front and back. The only caveat: It’s a good idea to hold on to the physical check until the deposit clears. Same deal as receipts: It’s your only record should anything be digitally amiss.

Not Fighting the Fees

Not Fighting the Fees

Exorbitant ATM charges happen. Never hesitate to call your bank and push back. If you’re a good customer (and nicely explain the fact that you had zero options available), in most cases, they’ll do you a favor and refund the fees. Hey, $3 here and there adds up.

RELATED: 8 Times You Should Demand a Refund (and What the Heck to Say)
item.author: editor@purewow.com (PureWow)

item.title: The 9 Most Filling Foods for Weight Loss
item.description:
Image credit: Twenty20

Just because you’re trying to lose weight doesn’t mean you have to walk around feeling hungry. With some strategic planning, you can eat until you’re full without having to worry so much about the calorie count. Here, nine picks that will fill you up without filling you out.

RELATED: 7 Desserts That Might Help You Lose Weight

Image credit: Twenty20

Cruciferous Vegetables

Cruciferous Vegetables

Like broccoli, cabbage, cauliflower and kale. Since they’re mostly made up of water and fiber, they’ll fill you up quickly with volume, not calories. Not a fan of plain veggies? Toss them into a soup or omelet.

Image credit: Twenty20

Cheese

Cheese

Cue the applause. Dairy is packed with protein (which takes longer to digest and therefore keeps you sated), as well as calcium, which has been shown to reduce fat absorption. So go ahead and enjoy a few slivers in moderation.

RELATED: Cheese Addicts, Rejoice: Full-Fat is Healthier Than Low-Fat

Image credit: Twenty20

Raspberries

Raspberries

Craving something sweet? Reach for a handful of raspberries. All berries—including strawberries and blueberries—are healthy snacks, but raspberries have the most fiber, with 8 grams per cup (and only 65 calories).

Image credit: Twenty20

Legumes

Legumes

They’re delicious, inexpensive and loaded with fiber and protein. And there are so many varieties—from navy beans to lentils to chickpeas—that you won’t fatigue your taste buds. Add a cup to your soups and salads or eat them as a side.

Image credit: Twenty20

Broth

Broth

Swap creamy soups for meat or veggie broths instead. While you’re at it, pack them full of vegetables and lean protein, like chicken. Slurping a bowl of soup will instantly fill your stomach and help you eat less overall.

Image credit: Twenty20

Almond Butter

Almond Butter

This creamy nut butter is far superior to its peanutty relative, as it has more calcium, protein and fiber per spoonful for about the same number of calories. Spread it onto some apple slices to up the fiber intake.

Image credit: Twenty20

Smoothies

Smoothies

In addition to being packed with fibrous fruits and vegetables, smoothies are full of air. So the longer you blend them (we suggest a full four to five minutes), the more frothy and filling they become.

RELATED: This Secret Ingredient Will Seriously Upgrade Your Smoothie

Image credit: Twenty20

Apples and Pears

Apples and Pears

Both fruits contain a special type of fiber called pectin that’s effective at slowing down digestion, keeping you feeling fuller longer. Midday munchies? Grab a pear and chomp away.

Image credit: Twenty20

Popcorn

Popcorn

Maybe Olivia Pope was onto something with her giant bowls of popcorn. It’s actually a great source of fiber and whole grains. To keep the calories in check, skip the butter and opt for a sprinkle of salt and pepper (or other savory seasonings like garlic and rosemary) instead.

RELATED: Whoa, Eating a Bowl of Popcorn for Dinner Is Healthier Than Pasta
item.author: editor@purewow.com (PureWow)

item.title: 3 Easy Ways to Unsubscribe to All of Your Annoying Emails
item.description:
Checking Gmail used to be fun...before it became a black hole of store marketing and spam. Here, three super-simple ways to clear your inbox of clutter for good. (Except for your day-making PureWow emails, of course.)

RELATED: 5 Secrets of People With “Zero” Inboxes

Image credit: Twenty20

Take a Shortcut to Unsubscribing

Take a Shortcut to Unsubscribing

If you’re using Gmail (in our opinion, the best), just open the message you no longer care to receive (say, from a retailer you shopped at once). To the right of the sender’s email address, you’ll see a button labeled Unsubscribe. Click it and a pop-up window should appear asking you to confirm the action. And then that’s it. Two seconds later, you’re off the list.

Image credit: Twenty20

Set Up a Filter

Set Up a Filter

Another Gmail hack: Simply check the box beside the email you no longer want to receive in your inbox and then click the More drop-down menu at the top of your inbox. There, you’ll see an option called Filter Messages Like These. A pop-up will appear with the sender’s email address already filled in. Click Create Filter With This Search in the bottom right-hand corner of the pop-up, select Delete It and then Create Filter. Going forward, all messages from that email address will be permanently blocked.

Image credit: Unroll.Me

Sign Up For UnRoll.Me

Sign Up For UnRoll.Me

Not using Gmail? UnRoll.Me is a free service that consolidates your newsletters into a neatly organized daily digest that you can review all in one shot. It works by scanning your inbox for subscriptions and then listing them all in alphabetical order so you can unsubscribe to the ones you no longer care to receive. Anything left goes into your daily roll-up.

RELATED: 6 Things to Remove From Your Laptop Right This Second
item.author: editor@purewow.com (PureWow)

item.title: Introducing Lip Liner and Lipstick in One Awesome Tube
item.description:
Image credit: Benefit Cosmetics

The thing about wearing lipstick—especially one in a statement shade like red—is that it can easily look sloppy without the help of some liner. But most of us don’t bother with the stuff because A) it’s another step to fuss with and B) it’s an extra product to buy and keep around. (Not to mention, when your lipstick fades, dark liner can go real ’90s, real fast.)

Enter Benefit’s new They're Real! Big Sexy Lip Kit, which takes the traditionally two-step (and two-product) process of lining and filling in your lips and packs it into one tube. 

How it works: Each lipstick has a split-tip bullet that’s shaped like a teardrop. The darker shade sits at the point, while its complimentary—and slightly lighter—hue sits directly below it. When you swipe the stick across your lips, the pointed end neatly defines the outer edges, while the creamy center fills in the rest. 

How to use them: Line up the point with your upper lip and glide the color on. To do your bottom lip, just flip the tip so that it’s facing down and swipe as you normally would. Press your lips together to softly blend and you’re good to go. 

Each kit costs $29 and comes with four palm-sized lipsticks: a coral, a fuchsia, a rosy nude and a cherry red. Here’s hoping they make full-size versions soon, because we have a feeling we're gonna run through these babies fast.

RELATED: 7 Fall Lipsticks We’re Really Excited to Wear

item.title: 8 Ways to Make Your Book Club Fun Again
item.description:
You love to read and see your friends, but lately your book club has been feeling a little, um, lame. Here, eight ways to breathe new life into your favorite literary hang.

RELATED: The 7 People in Every Book Club

Image credit: Twenty20

Send a Doodle to Coordinate Calendars

Send a Doodle to Coordinate Calendars

The most frustrating part of a book club? Finding a convenient time for everyone to meet. Your options: You can start what will become an annoyingly long group text chain. (Ugh, the worst.) Or you can rely on the Internet and send a Doodle, an online schedule solver that asks everyone to input their availability. Yay, at a glance you can see who’s free and when.

RELATED: Help! I Need Off This Horrible Group Text Message Chain!

Image credit: Twenty20

Then Decide What You'll Read Via an Online-Only Vote

Then Decide What You'll Read Via an Online-Only Vote

Picking a book doesn’t have to be tedious. Instead, invite the club members to submit book suggestions via email and then use Survey Monkey to generate a free survey where everyone can anonymously vote. Once the results are in, majority rules. Done and done.

RELATED: 10 Books Every Book Club Should Read

Image credit: Twenty20

Host a Book Club Brunch versus Dinner

Host a Book Club Brunch versus Dinner

We love baked ziti, but chatting about the latest Maria Semple novel over mimosas is a nice way to switch things up.

Image credit: Twenty20

Or Serve Cocktails and Snacks That Are on Theme

Or Serve Cocktails and Snacks That Are on Theme

It requires a bit of extra prep, but depending on what you’re reading, you can get creative by setting out drinks and food with subtle ties to the characters or plot. (An example: You could serve up Manhattans for NYC-set The Nest.)

Image credit: Amblin Entertainment

Watch the Movie Version of Whatever You Read

Watch the Movie Version of Whatever You Read

Your club elected to read Girl on the Train. Instead of meeting to discuss the book, get together to watch the movie in the theater. And this doesn’t just apply to new films. It works for older titles like The Joy Luck Club, too.

RELATED: 7 Books to Read Before They Become Movies

Image credit: Twenty20

Opt to Read Long Articles Instead

Opt to Read Long Articles Instead

If the members of your group are lamenting the fact that they have zero time to finish a book, make it easier on everyone and read a long article—like a deep analysis of the Brad and Angie breakup. Don’t worry, everyone can still vote on the selections, but the goal is to keep them short enough so that, worst-case scenario, everyone can plow through the article day-of.

RELATED: The Best Articles We Read In September

Image credit: Twenty20

Commit to Tackling a Recommended Reading List

Commit to Tackling a Recommended Reading List

The New York Times releases its annual “100 Notable Books” list at the end of every year. (Here’s the one from 2015.) Set a goal and make it your Everest: As a group, you will get through every single title on the list.

Image credit: Twenty20

Turn the Occasion Into a PotLuck (With Wine)

Turn the Occasion Into a Potluck (With Wine)

A food-free book club is the saddest book club. The host provides the entrée (something easy that you can make in a large batch, like chili) and everyone else brings an app—or a bottle of red.

RELATED: The Best Appetizer Recipes in the Whole Entire Universe
item.author: editor@purewow.com (PureWow)

item.title: The 5 Best Things You Can Do for Your Skin in Your 30s
item.description:
Image credit: Axelle/Getty Images

Ah, the ever-confusing 30s. You've finally (kinda) got your life together. Good job, cute house, a growing401(k). But what about your health? And, eek, your skin? Here are five things you might want to consider before lines and wrinkles set in.

1. Exfoliate regularly. A buildup of dead skin cells not only leads to breakouts (which, ugh, you're still susceptible to) but also deepens fine lines. Buff your face a few times a week with an apricot or peach scrub and you'll ward off both problems.

2. ﻿Lighten up on the twice-a-day washing. ﻿You're likely still in the habit of removing any and all oil from your face. But we're not teenagers anymore, ladies. Two heavy scrubbings a day might be overkill, causing dehydration and (later on) wrinkles. Instead, swap your evening routine for a gentle cleansing with micellar water.

3. Invest in a good eye cream. We know, the anti-aging market is daunting. But a lot of the products out right now are geared toward those who want to reverse the signs of aging. Skip past the BS and find a simple, thick hydrating cream. (We're fans of ones with avocado.)

4. Get on board with SPF. In your moisturizer. In your makeup. In a mist. Anything.

5. And get some shut-eye. No amount of creams and cleansers can replace a quality night's sleep. It gives your cells plenty of time to repair themselves. Trust: Your collagen will thank you.

﻿RELATED: ﻿6 Secrets of Women With Soft Skin
item.author: editor@purewow.com (PureWow)

item.title: 12 Things You Have to Eat in Philadelphia
item.description:
The City of Brotherly Love isn’t only about running up the steps of the art museum, Rocky-style (although that’s pretty fun, you should try it). It has also become a destination for some of the best food in the country, from tomato pie to hoagies to water ice. Here’s what you have to try when you visit.

RELATED: 12 Things You Have to Eat When You’re in New York

Image credit: Joy S./Yelp

Strawberry Lavender Doughnut at Federal DONUTS

Strawberry Lavender Doughnut at Federal DONUTS

Come for the sweet, fluffy doughnuts with just the right amount of sugar, and stay for the crispy fried chicken. (And yep, they’ll even let you get them all on one plate. Best meal ever.)

Multiple locations in Philadelphia; 267-928-3893 or federaldonuts.com

The Godfather Hoagie at Cosmi's Deli

The Godfather Hoagie at Cosmi's Deli

What’s a hoagie? When you’re in Philly, it’s a sub piled high with meat, cheese and veggies. The Godfather—with prosciutto, sopressata, mozzarella, roasted peppers, sun-dried tomatoes and green olives—is a must-try.

1501 S. Eighth St.; 215-468-6093 or cosmideli.com

Image credit: @chanwise/Instagram

Lemon Water Ice at John's

Lemon Water Ice at John's

This Italian ice (or “WOOD-er ice,” if you’re in Philly) is President Obama’s favorite. But if you’re not a sour fan, the pineapple is amazing, too.

701 Christian St.; 215-925-6955 or johnswaterice.com

Image credit: @phillyfoodforreal/Instagram

Tomato Pie at Marchiano's Bakery

Tomato Pie at Marchiano's Bakery

This regional treat is basically square pizza dough covered with crushed tomatoes and a sprinkle of Parmesan cheese. It’s available at bakeries and pizza shops all over the city, but here it’s arguably the best.

4635 Umbria St.; 215-483-8585 or marchianosbakery.com

Image credit: @rufio08/Instagram

Scrapple from Little Pete's

Scrapple from Little Pete's

OK, scrapple isn’t the most visually appealing food of all time. But when in Philly, you’ve gotta try the Pennsylvania Dutch delicacy made with pork scraps and cornmeal. Plus, it’s delicious on waffles.

219 S. 17th St.; 215-545-5508

Image credit: Sari Marissa G./Yelp

Cannoli at Termini Bros. Bakery

Cannoli at Termini Bros. Bakery

If you can’t swing a trip to Italy, these made-from-scratch desserts filled with ricotta cheese and chocolate chips are almost as amazing.

Multiple locations in Philadelphia; 215-334-1816 or termini.com

Image credit: Andres R./Yelp

Meatballs and Gravy at Villa Di Roma

Meatballs and Gravy at Villa Di Roma

This low-key Italian joint has been serving pasta in South Philly since 1963, so we’re pretty sure they know what they’re doing. But don’t you dare call it “tomato sauce.”

936 S. Ninth St.; 215-592-1295 or villadiroma.com

Image credit: John K./Yelp

Cheesesteak from John's Roast Pork

Cheesesteak from John's Roast Pork

Skip the touristy Pat’s and Geno’s and try this favorite of South Philly dockworkers instead. Keep it basic or add mushrooms and bacon. You can’t go wrong, we promise.

14 E. Snyder Ave.; 215-463-1951 or johnsroastpork.com

Image credit: @badkitty25/Instagram

Pho at Thang Long Noodle Restaurant

Pho at Thang Long Noodle Restaurant

Venture north to grab a piping-hot bowl of pho for breakfast. You can’t go wrong with either the chicken or beef broth here.

2534-36 Kensington Ave.; 215-425-0078

Image credit: I.J. E./Yelp

Tacos al Pastor at Mole Poblano

Tacos al Pastor at Mole Poblano

OK, Philly isn’t famous for its Mexican food, but if you’re having a Taco Tuesday craving, you can’t beat these guys made with thinly sliced pork shoulder. Seconds are encouraged.

1144 S. Ninth St.; 215-465-1616

Image credit: Mike C./Yelp

Pretzel with Garlic from Miller's Twist

Pretzel with Garlic from Miller's Twist

In Philly, you can’t go a block without hitting a pretzel store (and no, we’re not talking about Auntie Anne’s). These homemade twists topped with butter and garlic powder are as good as it gets.

51 N. Twelfth St.; 215-923-1723 or millerstwist.com

Image credit: High Street on Market

Forager Breakfast Sandwich from High Street on Market

Forager Breakfast Sandwich from High Street on Market

Don’t leave without trying this sammie with seared king oyster mushrooms, braised kale, a fried egg and Swiss cheese on homemade bread. Breakfast, lunch or dinner, it’ll be one of the best things you eat all year.

308 Market St.; 215-625-0988 or highstreetonmarket.com

RELATED: 19 Things You Need to Eat in Seattle Right Now

item.title: Why Teal Pumpkins Are Popping Up in Your Neighborhood This Year
item.description:
Image credit: @HolidayWorld/Twitter

Have you taken a walk around the neighborhood and noticed a sudden influx of teal-hued squash? Nope, it’s not a new varietal. And don’t worry—the official colors of Halloween haven’t changed, it’s still all about the orange and black.

It’s actually a really cool phenomenon. They’re part of the Teal Pumpkin Project, started by FARE﻿ (Food Allergy Research & Education) in an effort to make Halloween trick-or-treating safer for kids with food allergies.

Here’s how it works: Painting a pumpkin teal and putting it on your doorstep signals that you are handing out non-edible goodies like spider rings or glow sticks instead of potentially tricky Snickers and Almond Joy. 

So if your child is allergic to peanuts, just modify your usual route to hit up only the houses decked out with teal pumpkins. There’s even a map on FARE's website that shows all participating addresses in your area so families can find food-safe homes. Sweet.

RELATED: 12 Adorable Kids' Halloween Costumes You Should Order Now
item.author: editor@purewow.com (PureWow)

item.title: Why You Should Stop Putting Food in the Center of the Microwave
item.description:
Image credit: Claudiodivizia/Getty Images

You know every microwave trick in the book: the lazy way to clean it, how to keep your food from drying out when you reheat and even how to froth milk. But did you know you might be heating up food the wrong way? Let us explain.

So, microwaves cook with—you guessed it—microwaves. And while they’re great at heating up the water molecules they come in contact with, they don’t actually cover the entirety of the chamber. This means that lots of microwaves (like maybe the older one in your office) have cold spots—which explains why sometimes you take out your matzo-ball soup and it’s piping hot, but one whole side of the matzo ball is cold. 

Here’s how to fix it: Simply place your dish on the edge of the rotating carousel instead of in the center. This way, your food will travel through both hot and cold spots at different angles. So distribute the wealth, er, heat. And then go enjoy your soup.

RELATED: 9 Surprising Things You Can Cook in the Microwave
item.author: editor@purewow.com (PureWow)

item.title: How to Chill Wine When You Don't Have All Day
item.description:
Image credit: Twenty20

It’s been a long day and all you want is to relax with a crisp glass of Sauv Blanc. The only problem? You didn’t think far enough in advance to stick one in the refrigerator to chill. No worries, thanks to this super-easy trick for chilling a bottle in a hurry.

What you need: Ice, cold water, an ice bucket and salt.

What you do: In the ice bucket, mix the ice, water and a few handfuls of salt until evenly distributed. Then add the bottle of wine to the mixture and wait for the magic to happen. (A room-temp bottle should be sufficiently chilled in less than an hour.)

Why it works: Salt lowers the freezing point of water and lets it get colder without turning to ice. That means the frigid water can completely envelop the bottle while also drawing heat out of it, cooling the wine in no time.

Because happy hour waits for no woman. 

RELATED: 8 Things a Real Wine-Lover Would Never Do
item.author: editor@purewow.com (PureWow)

item.title: 6 Proven Ways to Keep Your Summer Energy Through Fall and Winter
item.description:
Summer is the best (duh), and the end of summer is the worst (duh). But it doesn’t have to be. Especially if you follow these six proven steps to keep your summer energy from dipping as the temperature does.

RELATED: Feeling Anxious? Here’s an Easy, Awesome Fix

Image credit: Twenty20

Go Outside

Go Outside

This one isn’t doable in, like, a blizzard. But when you can, go outside to boost your mood. Studies have shown that even on cold and cloudy days, outdoor light can combat seasonal affective disorder—especially when experienced within a few hours of waking up.

Image credit: Twenty20

Plan Your Next Vacation

Plan Your Next Vacation

One way to make it through the winter with your energy levels intact is to have something to look forward to—a light at the end of the cold tunnel, if you will. Per a 2010 study of people in the Netherlands, those who had vacations planned experienced a spike in pre-trip happiness. The anticipation of a fun getaway boosts your mood in the days, weeks and months leading up to it—even when the thermometer reads -10°F.

Image credit: Twenty20

Eat the Right Foods

Eat the Right Foods

When it’s cold and miserable outside, we often want to curl up with food that’s warm, comforting and not necessarily healthy. But before you dig into a vat of mac and cheese, consider that certain foods work wonders for boosting your mood. As the weather gets colder, drink milk for vitamin D (which you normally get from sun exposure), snack on pumpkin seeds for zinc (which helps the body fight off inflammation) and sprinkle cinnamon (which helps combat anxiety and depression) into your morning coffee. 

RELATED: A Sneaky Little Cinnamon Trick for Your Morning Coffee

Image credit: Twenty20

Make a Killer Playlist

Make a Killer Playlist

When we’re having a bad day, one of the first things we do is pop in our earbuds and fire up our favorite playlist. Turns out, we’ve been on to something. A study by the University of Missouri found that upbeat music can positively affect your mood. The study compared the moods of two groups listening to cheerier music by Copland and more somber music by Stravinsky, so just imagine what the new Regina Spektor album could do for you.

Image credit: Twenty20

Get Moving

Get Moving

We know, you’ve heard it a million times, but exercise really is a miracle worker when it comes to putting a little pep in your step. A 2013 study at Harvard University found that participants who walked briskly for about 35 minutes a day five times a week improved symptoms of mild to moderate depression. If you can’t get outside in the middle of the winter, consider hitting a fun class at the gym or even doing a quick YouTube workout from the comfort of home.

RELATED: 21 Fun Ways to Exercise If You Hate the Gym

Image credit: Twenty20

Be Mindful

Be Mindful

Mindfulness meditation—basically, focusing your attention and doing nothing—has been shown to decrease feelings of depression, anxiety and stress. It’s also really easy to do: Once or twice a day, sit in a comfortable position in a quiet room and just breathe while becoming hyperaware of your body. It’s relaxing, it relieves stress and it might help dissolve negative feelings.

RELATED: 8 Things That Might Happen If You Start Meditating
item.author: editor@purewow.com (PureWow)

item.title: The 8 Most Ridiculously Comfortable Trends of Fall 2016
item.description:
We’ve all suffered in the name of fashion: sky-high heels, too-tight jeans, that one regrettable haircut (OK, maybe that one was a different kind of suffering). Fortunately, this season has been a gold mine of trends that feel as good as they look. Here are eight pieces you’re gonna want to wear nonstop. 

RELATED: The Most Walkable Shoes That Are Still Trendy and Cute

Image credit: Vanni Bassetti/Getty Images

Wide-Legged Pants

Wide-Leg Pants

Think of these as a breezy, goes-with-everything alternative to a maxi skirt. Try a classic crepe that can be smartened up with heels for work or dressed down with sneaks for the weekend.

Get the look: H&M ($20); BB Dakota ($88); Joe's ($218)

Image credit: Edward Berthelot/Getty Images

Block-Heeled Booties

Block-Heeled Booties

Don’t be fooled by their rock-star good looks: These babies are actually super comfortable, thanks to a wobble-proof chunky heel that gives you plenty of support. Whether you go for basic black or gem-toned velvet, your feet will thank you. 

Get the look: Zara ($100); Sam Edelman ($160); Ash ($250)

Image credit: Christian Vierig/Getty Images

Oversized Sweaters

Oversize Sweaters

We quite literally couldn’t get through fall without sweaters, so we’re stoked that this season’s iterations are slouchy and inviting, with on-trend details like funnel necks and bell sleeves. 

Get the look: Missguided ($48); Free People ($168); Vince ($365)

Image credit: Song of Style

Slip Dresses

Slip Dresses

How could you not want to wear what’s essentially a fancy nightgown? Throw on a tee underneath for an instant ’90s vibe or embrace the just-rolled-out-of-bed look with a cozy cardigan. 

Get the look: Urban Outfitters ($89); Raey ($195); DKNY ($398)

Image credit: Mireya Acierto/Getty Images

Flat Mules

Flat Mules

On that same note, this season’s slides and backless loafers are as close as you can get to wearing slippers all day. Thank you, fashion gods. 

Get the look: Steve Madden ($90); Nine West ($99); Rebecca Minkoff ($175)

Image credit: Timur Emek/Getty Images

Not-Skinny Jeans

Not-Skinny Jeans

Relaxed, vintage-inspired straight-leg jeans are the denim silhouette of the moment, and they just so happen to have miles more breathing room than their body-hugging predecessors. (We still love you, skinnies.)

Get the look: Banana Republic ($69); Levi’s ($158); Eileen Fisher ($198)

Image credit: Michelle Take Aim

Pinafore Dresses

Pinafore Dresses

There’s a reason we adults decided to steal this style from the young’uns: It’s unfussy while still looking totally polished, whether you pair it with a turtleneck or a collared blouse.

Get the look: Marks & Spencer ($96); Fifteen Twenty ($220); Rag & Bone ($550)

Image credit: Damsel in Dior

Head-to-Toe Knits

Head-to-Toe Knits

What’s better than a cozy sweater on its own? A cozy sweater with a matching skirt or pants. We’ve never been more excited for cold weather.

Get the look: ASOS sweater ($46) and pants ($49); Finders Keepers sweater ($150)and skirt ($130)

item.title: The Genius Mascara Trick We Learned from Jessica Alba
item.description:
Image credit: Vittorio Zunino Celotto/Getty Images

Actress and billion-dollar-beauty-brand CEO Jessica Alba is no stranger to a good coat of mascara. So when we were scrolling through Snapchat recently and saw her giving the following tip on Vogue’s account, we were all ears. (Er, eyeballs.)

What you need: Your favorite mascara. Nothing different. 

What you do: Instead of holding your lashes still and swiping the wand through them, you do the opposite. Hold your wand still and bat your eyelashes on top of it. 

Why it works: According to Alba, the unsteadiness of your hand can cause you to smudge the formula onto your eyelids and surrounding skin. But by holding the wand in place, you get a much more even application.

So? Let your lashes do the work, and you’re thismuch closer to Alba status. 

RELATED: Watching Other People Put on Mascara Is the Best Thing Ever
